titleStmt.title: on the great Architect van B──

lg.l: When Mother Clud had risen from play
And cald to take the Cards away
Van Saw, but Seem'd not to regard
How Miss pick'd every painted Card:
And busy both with hand & eye,
Soon rear'd an house two Storyes high.
Vans Genius without thought or lecture,
Thus hugely turn'd to Architecture:
Hee Saw ye Edifice & Smil'd
Vow'd it was pretty for a chil'd:
It was so perfect in its kind,
Hee kept the model in his mind.
But when he found the boys at play,
And saw them dabling in their clay,
Hee stood behind a Stall to lurk
And mark the progress of their work;
With true delight observ'd them all
Raking up mud to build a wall;
The plan he much admir'd & took,
The model in his Table-book:
Thought himself now exactly Skilld
And so resolvd an house to buil'd
A real house with rooms & Stairs,
Five times at least as big as theirs.
Taller than Misses by two yards
Not a Sham-thing of clay or Cards,
And so he did, for in a While
Hee built up such a monstrous pile,
That no Chairman could be found
Able to lift it from ye: ground.
Still at Whitehall it Stands in View,
Iust in ye Place where first it grew;
There all ye little school-boys run
Envying to See themselves outdone.
From such deep rudiments as these
Van is become by due d,Egrees.
For. building fam'd; & justly reckon'd,
At Court Vitruvius ye Second;
No wonder since wise Authors Shew,
The best foundations must be low:
And now ye Duke has wisely ta'ne him,
To be his Architect at Bleinheim.
But raillery for once apart
If this rule holds in every Art:
Or if his Grace was no more skill'd in
The Art of battering walls than building,
Wee might expert to find next year,
A mouse-trapman Cheif Engineer.086-210L
